<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.652(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>96.14(3)°; <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: triclinic, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.1788(2), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.952 (3), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.968(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>94.400(3)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>92.260(4), <ce:italic>γ</ce:italic>

However, due to the existence of the second ligand-4,4′-bipy, the complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are a two-dimensional layer, the Lanthanide contraction makes the difference of the structure between the complexes at the same time. elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three rare-earth complexes with 3-methylbenzoic acid (HL) have been hydrothermally synthesized directly: Yb(C8H7O2)3 1 and Ln(C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5 (Ln=Eu 2, Gd 3) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine).The crystal structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction with the following data: 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a =13.574(3), b =8.0438(2), c =20.652(4)Å, β =96.14(3)°; 2: triclinic, P-1, a =8.1788(2), b =12.952 (3), c =12.968(3)Å, α =94.400(3)°, β =92.260(4), γ =101.360(4); the complex 1 is a one-dimensional chain. However, due to the existence of the second ligand-4,4'-bipy, the complexes 2 and 3 are a two-dimensional layer, the Lanthanide contraction makes the difference of the structure between the complexes at the same time. Additionally, in order to explore the structural characteristic, the 2D-IR correlation spectroscopy containing the temperature-induced structural variations and magnetism-induced structural variations is used. Photo-luminescent properties of 1 and 2 are discussed in detail.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Because of the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) intriguing topological structure and potential application as functional materials, such as magnetism, zelite-like catalysis activity, gas storage, ion change and optical properties, etc. , they always attracts great attentions. Due to the diversity of the coordination modes of carboxylate groups to metal atoms, the carboxylate-containing ligands can come into being many novel structures. The rare-earth ions not only having large radii and high coordination number but also having very stronger luminescence are widely applied in constructing the supra-molecular architectures. The coordination compound of rare-earth ion and carboxylate already have been studied over the past decade, which contains benzoic acid and its derivative ligands, for example: (1) 2-nitrobenzoic acid, 3-nitrobenzoic acid and 4-nitrobenzoic acid ; (2) 3-methoxybenzoic acid and 2,3-dimethoxybenzoic acid ; (3) amino-benzoic acid ; (4) hydroxyl-benzoic acid  and other intricate compounds . However, these compounds are merely the coordination mode of the rare-earth ions and the carboxylate group, and mainly the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group is coordinated with the rare-earth ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Because of the metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) intriguing topological structure and potential application as functional materials, such as magnetism, zelite-like catalysis activity, gas storage, ion change and optical properties, etc. , they always attracts great attentions. Due to the diversity of the coordination modes of carboxylate groups to metal atoms, the carboxylate-containing ligands can come into being many novel structures. The rare-earth ions not only having large radii and high coordination number but also having very stronger luminescence are widely applied in constructing the supra-molecular architectures. The coordination compound of rare-earth ion and carboxylate already have been studied over the past decade, which contains benzoic acid and its derivative ligands, for example: (1) 2-nitrobenzoic acid, 3-nitrobenzoic acid and 4-nitrobenzoic acid ; (2) 3-methoxybenzoic acid and 2,3-dimethoxybenzoic acid ; (3) amino-benzoic acid ; (4) hydroxyl-benzoic acid  and other intricate compounds . However, these compounds are merely the coordination mode of the rare-earth ions and the carboxylate group, and mainly the oxygen atom of the carboxylate group is coordinated with the rare-earth ion.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Now the key question is how to make the structure novel and innovative, which requires that the second ligand joins into the coordination compounds. The second ligand will make the structure very rich and colorful. The second ligand can change the zero-dimension into one-dimension or one-dimension chain into two-dimension layered structure by the second ligand functioning as the bridge. In addition, the important property of the rare-earth ions is lanthanide contraction, which affects the coordination-mode of the rare-earth ion. The effect of the lanthanide contraction on the structure of the rare-earth compounds has been reported  that three different structures, namely two-dimensional single layer, two-dimensional double layer and three-dimensional array are obtained by the coordination of 3,5-pyrazoldicarboxylic acid and lanthanide (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La, Ce, Eu, Er and Lu). The crystal structures of these complexes indicate that their dimensional diversity is controlled by lanthanide contraction .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Now the key question is how to make the structure novel and innovative, which requires that the second ligand joins into the coordination compounds. The second ligand will make the structure very rich and colorful. The second ligand can change the zero-dimension into one-dimension or one-dimension chain into two-dimension layered structure by the second ligand functioning as the bridge. In addition, the important property of the rare-earth ions is lanthanide contraction, which affects the coordination-mode of the rare-earth ion. The effect of the lanthanide contraction on the structure of the rare-earth compounds has been reported  that three different structures, namely two-dimensional single layer, two-dimensional double layer and three-dimensional array are obtained by the coordination of 3,5-pyrazoldicarboxylic acid and lanthanide (Ln=La, Ce, Eu, Er and Lu). The crystal structures of these complexes indicate that their dimensional diversity is controlled by lanthanide contraction .

<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and Ln(C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Eu <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, Gd <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine). Due to the entry of the second ligand-4,4′-bipy in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, their structures are obviously different from <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, The aim is that whether the second ligand-4,4′-bipy coordinates with the rare-earth ions, which decides the structure of the rare-earth complexes. The influence of the second ligand-4, 4′-bipy and lanthanide contraction on the structure of three rare-earth complexes have been studied. Due to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are iso-structural, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was only researched.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In order to further investigate the structure characteristics of the rare-earth complexes with 3-methylbenzoic acid (HL) and gain better knowledge on the different factors that may influence the structure of the rare-earth complexes, we have synthesized Yb(C8H7O2)3 1 and Ln(C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5 (Ln=Eu 2, Gd 3) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine). Due to the entry of the second ligand-4,4'-bipy in 2 and 3, their structures are obviously different from 1, The aim is that whether the second ligand-4,4'-bipy coordinates with the rare-earth ions, which decides the structure of the rare-earth complexes. The influence of the second ligand-4, 4'-bipy and lanthanide contraction on the structure of three rare-earth complexes have been studied. Due to 2 and 3 are iso-structural, 2 was only researched.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR Fourier transform spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The temperature variation was controlled by a Portable programmable temperature controller (Model 50–886, Love Control Corporation) during the process of increasing temperature from 323 to 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at intervals of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The magnetism variation was made by ourselves and its rang is 0–50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mT. 2D-IR correlation spectra were obtained by treatment of the series of dynamic spectra with 2D-COS IR correlation analysis software provided by Tsinghua University. The luminescence spectra were reported on an Edinburgh-Instrument spectra-Fluorimeter (solid).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. The IR spectra were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 2000 FT-IR Fourier transform spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range 400-4000cm-1. The temperature variation was controlled by a Portable programmable temperature controller (Model 50-886, Love Control Corporation) during the process of increasing temperature from 323 to 393K at intervals of 10K. The magnetism variation was made by ourselves and its rang is 0-50mT. 2D-IR correlation spectra were obtained by treatment of the series of dynamic spectra with 2D-COS IR correlation analysis software provided by Tsinghua University. The luminescence spectra were reported on an Edinburgh-Instrument spectra-Fluorimeter (solid).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Yb (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Yb·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.076<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,4′-bipy (0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), absolute ethanol (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and pH 4 were sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2d and then cooled to room temperature at 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Very longer colorless needle crystals for 1 were obtained. IR data (KBr pellet, <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic> [cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>]): 3449, 2922, 1732, 1636, 1595, 1527, 1487, 1408, 1287, 1226, 1165, 1084, 807, 785, 756, 669, 578, 517, 490, 438.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Yb (C8H7O2)3] 1 

Compound 1 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (CH3COO)3Yb⋅4H2O (0.25mmol, 0.076g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25mmol, 0.045g), 4,4'-bipy (0.05g), absolute ethanol (1mL), H2O (4mL) and pH 4 were sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150°C for 2d and then cooled to room temperature at 24h. Very longer colorless needle crystals for 1 were obtained. IR data (KBr pellet, υ [cm-1]): 3449, 2922, 1732, 1636, 1595, 1527, 1487, 1408, 1287, 1226, 1165, 1084, 807, 785, 756, 669, 578, 517, 490, 438.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Eu (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and [Gd (C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of Eu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.107<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.045<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,4′-bipyridine (0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), absolute ethanol (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and pH 4 was sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2d, and then cooled to room temperature at 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The synthesis of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is similar to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, only the Eu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was replaced by the Gd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Light yellow needle crystals for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained IR data (KBr pellet, <ce:italic>υ</ce:italic> [cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>]): 3059, 2920, 1596, 1530, 1487, 1408, 1286, 1226, 1086, 1068, 1042, 999, 911, 804, 758, 685, 676, 616, 570, 516, 489, 421.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Eu (C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5] 2 and [Gd (C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5] 3 

Compound 2 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of Eu(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.25mmol, 0.107g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25mmol, 0.045g), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.05g), absolute ethanol (1mL), H2O (4mL) and pH 4 was sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150°C for 2d, and then cooled to room temperature at 24h. The synthesis of 3 is similar to 2, only the Eu(NO3)3⋅5H2O was replaced by the Gd(NO3)3⋅5H2O. Light yellow needle crystals for 2 were obtained IR data (KBr pellet, υ [cm-1]): 3059, 2920, 1596, 1530, 1487, 1408, 1286, 1226, 1086, 1068, 1042, 999, 911, 804, 758, 685, 676, 616, 570, 516, 489, 421.

X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1 were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID diffractometer with graphite mono-chromatized MoKα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Suitable single crystals of 2 and 3 were mounted on glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite mono-chromatized MoKα radiation (λ =0.7107Å). Crystal structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques against F2  using the SHELXS-97  crystallographic software package. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anis-tropically. Hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. All calculations were performed using the SHELXL-97  program. The Crystal data 1, 2 and 3 were given in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1 and 2 were listed in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 3 was listed in  .

Results and discussion

Structural descriptions of [Yb (C8H7O2)3] 1 and [Eu (C8H7O2)3  ⋅ (4,4'-bipy)0.5] 2  

The X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that the structure of 1 is a one-dimensional chain framework, crystallizing in monoclinic space group p21/n. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains three HLs. The Yb ion is coordinated with seven oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxyl group (O5 and O6) and five dimonodentate carboxyl groups(O1, O2A, O3, O4 and O7A), as shown in  . The average distance of Yb-O is 2.2922(8)Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a two-dimensional layer framework, crystallizing in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-1. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains three 3-methylbenzoic acids and half the 4,4′-bipy. The Eu ion is coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from one chelating bi-dentate carboxyl group (O9A and O9B) and five dimonodentate carboxyl groups(O1, O4, O5, O7A and O8A). However, the most interesting thing is N1 from 4, 4′-bipy coordinating with Eu atom, which is very rare in the rare-earth compounds, as shown in

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">By carefully studying two structures, we find that in two compounds, the coordination mode of HL is very interesting: the carboxyl group of 3-methylbenzoic acid has two kinds of coordination mode, one kind is that one oxygen of the carboxyl group connects two metal ions, and the other connects one metal ion, namely it adopts the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging coordination mode . The Eu–O bonds of two carboxyl groups which adopt the coordination mode form a rhombus, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig7"></ce:float-anchor>. The other kind is one oxygen of the carboxyl group connects one metal ion, and the other connects one metal ion, namely it adopts the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging coordination mode, two carboxyl groups linked to the metal, respectively, form two eight-rings approximately perpendicularly, which makes four ligands steady. But the subsistent format of two kinds of the carboxyl group coordination mode is very different, (as it is shown in the following 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>, the green line presents the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging coordination mode and the yellow line represents the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging coordination mode) that is the yellow line and the green line form a helix chain respectively in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (), however, the yellow line and the green line both appear conjugated independently in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (). It is likely to the character of the central metal ion and the entry of the second ligand. At the same time, compared to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the characteristic structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is that there are the right-handed helices and left-handed helices running along crystallographic <ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> axis in <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction respectively, the helical pitch lengths are both 8.0438(16)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). Furthermore, the left-handed helices chain is composed of the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging carboxyl group and another is the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging carboxyl group.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By carefully studying two structures, we find that in two compounds, the coordination mode of HL is very interesting: the carboxyl group of 3-methylbenzoic acid has two kinds of coordination mode, one kind is that one oxygen of the carboxyl group connects two metal ions, and the other connects one metal ion, namely it adopts the μ3-η2-η1-bridging coordination mode . The Eu-O bonds of two carboxyl groups which adopt the coordination mode form a rhombus, as shown in   . The other kind is one oxygen of the carboxyl group connects one metal ion, and the other connects one metal ion, namely it adopts the μ2-η1-η1-bridging coordination mode, two carboxyl groups linked to the metal, respectively, form two eight-rings approximately perpendicularly, which makes four ligands steady. But the subsistent format of two kinds of the carboxyl group coordination mode is very different, (as it is shown in the following   , the green line presents the μ2-η1-η1-bridging coordination mode and the yellow line represents the μ3-η2-η1-bridging coordination mode) that is the yellow line and the green line form a helix chain respectively in 1 (), however, the yellow line and the green line both appear conjugated independently in 2 (). It is likely to the character of the central metal ion and the entry of the second ligand. At the same time, compared to 2, the characteristic structure of 1 is that there are the right-handed helices and left-handed helices running along crystallographic 21  axis in a direction and c direction respectively, the helical pitch lengths are both 8.0438(16)Å (). Furthermore, the left-handed helices chain is composed of the μ2-η1-η1-bridging carboxyl group and another is the μ3-η2-η1-bridging carboxyl group.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Influence of the second ligand-4,4′-bipy and lanthanide contraction on the structure of the compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">By the analysis of the above structural descriptions, we know that the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> forms a one-dimensional chain () structure, nevertheless the complexe <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> forms a two-dimensional layer structure (). It is well known to all, the properties of the lanthanide are mostly influenced by the lanthanide contraction. Due to the position of Eu atom taking precedence over that of Yb atom, the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> radii is larger than the Yb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> radii, the coordination number of the Eu ion is more than the coordination number of the Yb ion, therefore the Eu ion has bigger space to coordinate with the ligand, the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is eight-coordinated and the Yb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is seven-coordinated, the excessive coordination number of the Eu<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is occupied by the N atom of 4,4′-bipy, in this way, the second ligand-4,4′-bipy is linked to the one-dimension chain making up of the Eu ion and the ligand-HL, the 4,4′-bipy ligand functioned as a bridge. The second ligand introduced into the structure makes the structure change from one dimension to two-dimensional and from the chain to the layer. It makes the simple structure into the rich and colorful.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Influence of the second ligand-4,4'-bipy and lanthanide contraction on the structure of the compounds

By the analysis of the above structural descriptions, we know that the complex 1 forms a one-dimensional chain () structure, nevertheless the complexe 2 forms a two-dimensional layer structure (). It is well known to all, the properties of the lanthanide are mostly influenced by the lanthanide contraction. Due to the position of Eu atom taking precedence over that of Yb atom, the Eu3+ radii is larger than the Yb3+ radii, the coordination number of the Eu ion is more than the coordination number of the Yb ion, therefore the Eu ion has bigger space to coordinate with the ligand, the Eu3+ is eight-coordinated and the Yb3+ is seven-coordinated, the excessive coordination number of the Eu3+ is occupied by the N atom of 4,4'-bipy, in this way, the second ligand-4,4'-bipy is linked to the one-dimension chain making up of the Eu ion and the ligand-HL, the 4,4'-bipy ligand functioned as a bridge. The second ligand introduced into the structure makes the structure change from one dimension to two-dimensional and from the chain to the layer. It makes the simple structure into the rich and colorful.

elements.clean_text:
Photo-luminescent properties

The luminescent behaviors of 1 and 2 were researched in the solid state at room temperature. When excited at 285nm, there is a very strong and speculate emission peak at 978nm for 1 at room temperature, which is shown in the  (a). The emission peaks of the compounds correspond to the transitions from 2F5/2-2F7/2 at 978nm for Yb3+ ion in 1. When excited at 280nm for 2, it emits red light at room temperature ((b)).The emission peaks of 2 corresponds to the transitions from 5D0-7Fn (n =1, 2, 3, and 4) at 592,618,652,700nm for Eu3+ ion in 2 . Among those emission lines, the most remarkable red emissions (5D0-7F2) for 2 are observed in their emission spectra.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the (b), the remarkable point is that the absorption peak of 1646<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> suddenly appears in the range of 323–333<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, this 1646<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> absorption peak did not appear at the room temperature, it is attributed to the stretching vibrations of the uncoordinated carboxylate groups, by analyzing the coordination mode and the bond lengths of Eu–O, we find that there is the longest Eu–O (2.651(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) in the μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-bridging coordination mode which is very unstable, when the temperature heats up to 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, this bond easily disconnects and the identical oxygen linked to another Eu–O bond strengthens.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the (b), the remarkable point is that the absorption peak of 1646cm-1 suddenly appears in the range of 323-333K in 2, this 1646cm-1 absorption peak did not appear at the room temperature, it is attributed to the stretching vibrations of the uncoordinated carboxylate groups, by analyzing the coordination mode and the bond lengths of Eu-O, we find that there is the longest Eu-O (2.651(3)Å) in the μ3-η2-η1-bridging coordination mode which is very unstable, when the temperature heats up to 325K, this bond easily disconnects and the identical oxygen linked to another Eu-O bond strengthens.

Magnetism-induced structural variations in the compounds revealed by 2D-IR correlation spectroscopy are shown in (a) and (b).

In the (a), the wave-number 1300-1600cm-1 has the strong induction to the magnetism in 1: the strong auto peaks along the diagonal line are unambiguously detected at 1560 and 1476cm-1 which indicates the intensity change of υ (COO) band is sensitive to the magnetism variation in the synchronous correlation spectrum. From the asynchronous correlation spectrum, the responses at the cross-peaks at (1370, 1560cm-1), (1345, 1560cm-1) and (1476, 1560cm-1) are positive, however, those cross-peaks are negative in the synchronous correlation spectrum, according to the rule of Noda , which indicates that the IR intensity variation observed at wave-number 1560cm-1 occurs predominantly before that at 1345, 1370, 1476cm-1. The complexe 1 is sensitive to the magnetism, which reveals that the Yb3+ has a single electron.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The rare-earth compounds with HL have been hydrothermally synthesized. Due to the existence of the second bridging ligand-4,4′-bipy, the complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are two-dimensional layer. <ce:bold>1 is</ce:bold> one-dimensional chain. Synchronously the influence of lanthanide contraction on their structure should also be taken into consideration. Two types of the bridging coordination mode namely μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>–η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> coexist in two complexes. Photo-luminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are discussed in detail. They emit green or red luminescence at room temperature respectively, so they could be applied to potential fluorescent materials . In addition, we firstly try to introduce 2D-IR correlation spectroscopy to the structural analysis of two compounds especially to the coordinated carboxyl group. The results indicate that 2D-COS IR can not only improve to recognize the structure of MOFs, but also provide valuable dynamic information for the in-depth study of MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The rare-earth compounds with HL have been hydrothermally synthesized. Due to the existence of the second bridging ligand-4,4'-bipy, the complexes 2 and 3 are two-dimensional layer. 1 is one-dimensional chain. Synchronously the influence of lanthanide contraction on their structure should also be taken into consideration. Two types of the bridging coordination mode namely μ3-η2-η1 and μ2-η1-η1 coexist in two complexes. Photo-luminescent properties of 1 and 2 are discussed in detail. They emit green or red luminescence at room temperature respectively, so they could be applied to potential fluorescent materials . In addition, we firstly try to introduce 2D-IR correlation spectroscopy to the structural analysis of two compounds especially to the coordinated carboxyl group. The results indicate that 2D-COS IR can not only improve to recognize the structure of MOFs, but also provide valuable dynamic information for the in-depth study of MOFs.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Yb (C8H7O2)3] 1 

Compound 1 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of (CH3COO)3Yb⋅4H2O (0.25mmol, 0.076g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25mmol, 0.045g), 4,4'-bipy (0.05g), absolute ethanol (1mL), H2O (4mL) and pH 4 were sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150°C for 2d and then cooled to room temperature at 24h. Very longer colorless needle crystals for 1 were obtained. IR data (KBr pellet, υ [cm-1]): 3449, 2922, 1732, 1636, 1595, 1527, 1487, 1408, 1287, 1226, 1165, 1084, 807, 785, 756, 669, 578, 517, 490, 438.

Synthesis of [Eu (C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5] 2 and [Gd (C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5] 3 

Compound 2 was prepared by hydrothermal reaction. A mixture of Eu(NO3)3⋅5H2O (0.25mmol, 0.107g), 3-methylbenzoic acid (0.25mmol, 0.045g), 4,4'-bipyridine (0.05g), absolute ethanol (1mL), H2O (4mL) and pH 4 was sealed into a bomb equipped with a teflon liner, heated at 150°C for 2d, and then cooled to room temperature at 24h. The synthesis of 3 is similar to 2, only the Eu(NO3)3⋅5H2O was replaced by the Gd(NO3)3⋅5H2O. Light yellow needle crystals for 2 were obtained IR data (KBr pellet, υ [cm-1]): 3059, 2920, 1596, 1530, 1487, 1408, 1286, 1226, 1086, 1068, 1042, 999, 911, 804, 758, 685, 676, 616, 570, 516, 489, 421.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three rare-earth complexes with 3-methylbenzoic acid (HL) have been hydrothermally synthesized directly: Yb(C8H7O2)3 1 and Ln(C8H7O2)3⋅(4,4'-bipy)0.5 (Ln=Eu 2, Gd 3) (4,4'-bipy=4,4'-bipyridine).The crystal structures were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction with the following data: 1: monoclinic, P21/n, a =13.574(3), b =8.0438(2), c =20.652(4)Å, β =96.14(3)°; 2: triclinic, P-1, a =8.1788(2), b =12.952 (3), c =12.968(3)Å, α =94.400(3)°, β =92.260(4), γ =101.360(4); the complex 1 is a one-dimensional chain. However, due to the existence of the second ligand-4,4'-bipy, the complexes 2 and 3 are a two-dimensional layer, the Lanthanide contraction makes the difference of the structure between the complexes at the same time. Additionally, in order to explore the structural characteristic, the 2D-IR correlation spectroscopy containing the temperature-induced structural variations and magnetism-induced structural variations is used. Photo-luminescent properties of 1 and 2 are discussed in detail.

Results and discussion

Structural descriptions of [Yb (C8H7O2)3] 1 and [Eu (C8H7O2)3  ⋅ (4,4'-bipy)0.5] 2  

The X-ray crystal structure analysis reveals that the structure of 1 is a one-dimensional chain framework, crystallizing in monoclinic space group p21/n. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains three HLs. The Yb ion is coordinated with seven oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxyl group (O5 and O6) and five dimonodentate carboxyl groups(O1, O2A, O3, O4 and O7A), as shown in  . The average distance of Yb-O is 2.2922(8)Å.

Photo-luminescent properties

The luminescent behaviors of 1 and 2 were researched in the solid state at room temperature. When excited at 285nm, there is a very strong and speculate emission peak at 978nm for 1 at room temperature, which is shown in the  (a). The emission peaks of the compounds correspond to the transitions from 2F5/2-2F7/2 at 978nm for Yb3+ ion in 1. When excited at 280nm for 2, it emits red light at room temperature ((b)).The emission peaks of 2 corresponds to the transitions from 5D0-7Fn (n =1, 2, 3, and 4) at 592,618,652,700nm for Eu3+ ion in 2 . Among those emission lines, the most remarkable red emissions (5D0-7F2) for 2 are observed in their emission spectra.

At the room temperature, we obtain the luminescence decay curves of 2. ( ) The decay curves are well fitted into a double-exponential function as Fit (t)= A + B 1 e(-  t  /  Г  1) + B 2 e(-  t  /  Г  2), When excited at 280nm for 2, the tine and narrow emission peak at 618nm is measured, 2 has very long life scan, the τ 1 and τ 2 are 177.0 and 464.1μs, respectively. The value of X 2 is 1.298. The strong photoluminescence properties of 2 may make them excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials .
